questions.text: Which of the following can be used as an intravenous induction agent? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Propofol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Propofol is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent widely used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and produces a smooth and quick recovery, but can cause hypotension and respiratory depression.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic. It is not used as an intravenous induction agent for general anesthesia. Instead, it's used for regional anesthesia like epidural or nerve blocks. When administered systemically, it can be toxic, especially to the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  • • Option B. Bupivacaine:
  • • Option C. Dexmedetomidine: Dexmedetomidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It provides sedation without causing respiratory depression. Although it is used for sedation in the ICU and for certain procedures, it's not typically used as a primary induction agent for general anesthesia.
  • • Option C. Dexmedetomidine:
  • • Option D. Neostigmine : Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. It is used to reverse neuromuscular blockade (from non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers) at the end of a surgery. It is not used as an induction agent for anesthesia.
  • • Option D. Neostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Propofol is a widely used intravenous induction agent for general anesthesia due to its rapid onset and smooth recovery profile.

It is unique in its ability to rapidly and effectively reverse paralysis even shortly after rocuronium administration, making it the drug of choice in emergency situations where rapid recovery of muscle function is required.

questions.text: What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? ( INICET May 2023) 1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute 2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute 3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm 4. Allow chest recoil
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • High-Quality CPR Indicators:
  • • High-Quality CPR Indicators:
  • • 1. Chest Compression Rate: Chest compressions should be performed at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.
  • • 1. Chest Compression Rate:
  • • 3. Depth of Compression: Compressions should have a depth of 5-6 centimeters (2-2.4 inches).
  • • 3. Depth of Compression:
  • • 4. Chest Recoil: It is essential to allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to ensure adequate filling of the heart between compressions. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is in place, the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute.
  • • 4. Chest Recoil:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 2, 3 only: While a compression depth of 5-6 cm is correct, a breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not part of the indicators for high-quality CPR.
  • • Option A. 2, 3 only:
  • • Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4: Although chest compression rate, depth, and recoil are correct indicators, the breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not recommended for high-quality CPR.
  • • Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4:
  • • Option D. 1 only: While the correct chest compression rate is part of high-quality CPR, other factors like compression depth and chest recoil are also crucial.
  • • Option D. 1 only:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.
  • ➤ Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department in severe respiratory distress. On arrival, he is unable to speak in full sentences, and his oxygen saturation is 82% on room air. He rapidly becomes unresponsive, with worsening hypoxia despite non-invasive ventilation attempts. You are called to assist the Emergency Medical Officer in management of this patient. The image below shows the instruments available to you in the emergency cart. What is the primary use of these instruments in the context of the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: To perform chest tube insertion for pneumothorax

options.label: B
options.text: To establish central venous access in an emergency

options.label: C
options.text: To secure the airway through endotracheal intubation

options.label: D
options.text: To perform cardiac defibrillation in cardiac arrest

questions.correct_answer: C. To secure the airway through endotracheal intubation
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The instruments displayed in the image are components of an airway cart, which is essential in managing a compromised airway, particularly in emergency and anesthesia settings. These tools include laryngoscopes, endotracheal tubes, and other airway adjuncts that facilitate intubation—a procedure where a tube is inserted into the trachea to maintain an open airway. In this patient’s case, rapid deterioration of respiratory function necessitates securing the airway to prevent hypoxia, which can be life-threatening. Endotracheal intubation is the definitive intervention to stabilize the patient’s breathing in such critical scenarios.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) To perform chest tube insertion for pneumothorax: Chest tube insertion involves different equipment such as thoracostomy trays and is used specifically for draining air or fluid from the pleural space, not for airway management.
  • • Option A) To perform chest tube insertion for pneumothorax:
  • • Thoracostomy trays
  • • Option B) To establish central venous access in an emergency: Central venous access requires a central line kit and is used to administer medications, fluids, or for monitoring central venous pressure, unrelated to airway management.
  • • Option B) To establish central venous access in an emergency:
  • • Central line kit
  • • Option D) To perform cardiac defibrillation in cardiac arrest: Cardiac defibrillation requires a defibrillator and pads, used to restore normal heart rhythm in cases of cardiac arrest, and does not involve the equipment shown in the image.
  • • Option D) To perform cardiac defibrillation in cardiac arrest:
  • • Defibrillator and pads

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The instruments shown are primarily used for airway management, particularly endotracheal intubation, which is crucial in maintaining ventilation in patients experiencing respiratory failure or during anesthesia. Prompt and appropriate use of these tools can significantly improve patient outcomes in emergency scenarios involving compromised airways.

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in adults? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) L1-L2

Explanation:

  • • Termination of the Spinal Cord:
  • • Termination of the Spinal Cord:
  • • Anatomy: The spinal cord terminates at a region called the conus medullaris. Details: Below the conus medullaris, a bundle of spinal nerve roots continues downward, which is called the cauda equina (meaning "horse's tail" in Latin) due to its appearance. Adult Spinal Cord End: The lower end of the spinal cord in adults is at the lower border of L1.
  • • Anatomy: The spinal cord terminates at a region called the conus medullaris.
  • • Anatomy:
  • • Details: Below the conus medullaris, a bundle of spinal nerve roots continues downward, which is called the cauda equina (meaning "horse's tail" in Latin) due to its appearance.
  • • Details:
  • • Adult Spinal Cord End: The lower end of the spinal cord in adults is at the lower border of L1.
  • • Adult Spinal Cord End:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. L3-L4: This is incorrect as the spinal cord in adults does not extend to this level. This level is generally where lumbar punctures are performed to avoid the spinal cord.
  • • Option A. L3-L4:
  • • Option C. T12-L1: This is slightly higher than the actual end of the spinal cord in adults. The spinal cord terminates at L1-L2, not T12-L1.
  • • Option C. T12-L1:
  • • Option D. L2-L3: This is incorrect as well because the spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults, not extending to L2-L3.
  • • Option D. L2-L3:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spinal cord in adults terminates at the lower border of L1, at the region called the conus medullaris, with the cauda equina continuing downward from this point.

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2 to 8 mm Hg, SpO2 was 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mm Hg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18 mm Hg. Which of the most probable diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. CO2 embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the scenario described, a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 (etCO2) to 8 mm Hg, along with a drop in blood pressure (BP) to 80/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 90%, but with normal peak airway pressure (18 mm Hg), strongly suggests a CO2 embolism. During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used for insufflation to create a pneumoperitoneum, which can occasionally enter a blood vessel and cause a CO2 embolism. This event leads to a rapid decrease in etCO2 due to reduced return of CO2 to the lungs, hypoxemia, and cardiovascular collapse. The normal peak airway pressures help differentiate it from other causes of acute respiratory distress.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pneumothorax : A pneumothorax, or collapsed lung, could occur due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or surgical complications. However, it typically causes an increase in peak airway pressures due to increased resistance to ventilation. The absence of increased peak airway pressures makes pneumothorax less likely in this case.
  • • Option A. Pneumothorax
  • • Option C. Endobronchial Intubation : Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is inserted too far and intubates one of the main bronchi, typically the right main bronchus. This can lead to hypoventilation of one lung, causing a decrease in etCO2 and SpO2. However, peak airway pressures might be higher due to one-lung ventilation, which was not observed here.
  • • Option C. Endobronchial Intubation
  • • Option D. Bronchospasm : Bronchospasm involves the constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, leading to narrowed airways. This would usually present with an increase in peak airway pressures due to the narrowed airways, which is not consistent with the normal peak airway pressures reported in this scenario.
  • • Option D. Bronchospasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During laparoscopic surgery, the sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxemia, and a significant decrease in etCO2 with normal peak airway pressures suggests a CO2 embolism, a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

questions.text: Why is 100% oxygen given after nitrous oxide is stopped during the emergence from anesthesia? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: D
options.text: Because air is more expensive than oxygen

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • After discontinuing nitrous oxide (N2O), the gas can rapidly diffuse from the blood into the alveoli, which may dilute the oxygen levels in the lungs and lead to a condition known as diffusion hypoxia. To prevent this drop in oxygen levels, 100% oxygen is administered to ensure that the patient remains adequately oxygenated as they emerge from anesthesia.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Second gas effect: This effect is related to the rapid uptake of N2O enhancing the concentration of other anesthetic gases but is not the reason for administering 100% oxygen after stopping N2O.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option C . To provide adequate analgesia: Oxygen is not administered for analgesia purposes, making this option incorrect.
  • • Option
  • • C
  • • Option D. Because air is more expensive than oxygen: This is not a valid reason for using 100% oxygen in this scenario.
  • • Option
  • • D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Administering 100% oxygen after stopping nitrous oxide is crucial to prevent diffusion hypoxia and ensure proper oxygenation during the patient's recovery from anesthesia.

questions.text: Arrange the following anaethesia agents on the basis of their potency. (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Methoxyflurane>Halothane>Isoflurane>Nitrous oxide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Potency of Anesthetic Agents:
  • • Potency of Anesthetic Agents:
  • • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.
  • • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.
  • • MAC Values:
  • • MAC Values:
  • • Methoxyflurane: 0.16 Halothane: 0.75 Isoflurane: 1.4 Nitrous oxide: 104
  • • Methoxyflurane: 0.16
  • • Halothane: 0.75
  • • Isoflurane: 1.4
  • • Nitrous oxide: 104
  • • Order of Potency (from most potent to least potent):
  • • Order of Potency (from most potent to least potent):
  • • Methoxyflurane: With the lowest MAC of 0.16, it is the most potent agent. Halothane: With a MAC of 0.75, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane but more potent than Isoflurane and Nitrous oxide. Isoflurane: With a MAC of 1.4, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane and Halothane but more potent than Nitrous oxide. Nitrous oxide: With the highest MAC of 104, it is the least potent.
  • • Methoxyflurane: With the lowest MAC of 0.16, it is the most potent agent.
  • • Methoxyflurane:
  • • Halothane: With a MAC of 0.75, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane but more potent than Isoflurane and Nitrous oxide.
  • • Halothane:
  • • Isoflurane: With a MAC of 1.4, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane and Halothane but more potent than Nitrous oxide.
  • • Isoflurane:
  • • Nitrous oxide: With the highest MAC of 104, it is the least potent.
  • • Nitrous oxide:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane > Methoxyflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide has the highest MAC and is the least potent, while Methoxyflurane is the most potent.
  • • Option A. Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane > Methoxyflurane:
  • • Option C. Methoxyflurane > Isoflurane > Halothane > Nitrous oxide: Incorrect, as Halothane is more potent than Isoflurane.
  • • Option C. Methoxyflurane > Isoflurane > Halothane > Nitrous oxide:
  • • Option D. Methoxyflurane > Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide is the least potent and should be at the end of the sequence.
  • • Option D. Methoxyflurane > Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is inversely proportional to their MAC values. Methoxyflurane, with the lowest MAC, is the most potent, while Nitrous oxide, with the highest MAC, is the least potent. The correct order of potency is Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous oxide.
  • ➤ The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is inversely proportional to their MAC values. Methoxyflurane, with the lowest MAC, is the most potent, while Nitrous oxide, with the highest MAC, is the least potent. The correct order of potency is Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous oxide.

questions.text: Cardiac output can be determined using the following except? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Capnography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Capnography primarily measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air, which gives information about ventilation and metabolism. It does not measure cardiac output. Capnography is commonly used to monitor end-tidal CO2 and confirm tracheal intubation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Thermal dilution technique: The thermal dilution technique is a method used primarily with a pulmonary artery catheter (also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter). Cold saline is injected into the right atrium, and the change in blood temperature is measured as it passes a thermistor in the pulmonary artery. The degree of temperature change allows for the calculation of cardiac output. This method is invasive and provides continuous or intermittent measurements, depending on the specific catheter and monitor used.
  • • Option A. Thermal dilution technique:
  • • Option C. Esophageal Doppler: The esophageal Doppler uses ultrasound waves to measure blood flow velocity in the descending aorta via a probe placed in the esophagus. By knowing the cross-sectional area of the aorta and calculating the velocity of blood flow, cardiac output can be estimated.
  • • Option C. Esophageal Doppler:
  • • Option D. Echocardiography: Echocardiography, or cardiac ultrasound, allows for visualization of cardiac structures and blood flow. Cardiac output can be estimated by measuring the velocity of blood flow across the mitral or tricuspid valves and then multiplying this by the valve area.
  • • Option D. Echocardiography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air and is not used to determine cardiac output.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.
  • • Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 0.2 Hz : This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.
  • • Option A. 0.2 Hz
  • • Option B. 2 Hz : This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.
  • • Option B. 2 Hz
  • • Option C. 20 Hz : This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.
  • • Option C. 20 Hz

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.
  • ➤ PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:
  • ➤ PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Well controlled asthma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Well controlled asthma: Asthma, when well controlled, should not significantly increase the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. Uncontrolled or poorly controlled asthma, on the other hand, would be a risk factor due to increased airway hyperreactivity and potential for bronchospasm or other complications in the postoperative period.
  • • Well controlled asthma:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. BMI > 30: Obesity can reduce functional residual capacity and total lung volume, which increases the risk of atelectasis after surgery. Additionally, obese patients often have decreased diaphragmatic movement and may have associated conditions like obstructive sleep apnea, which can contribute to postoperative respiratory issues.
  • • Option A. BMI > 30:
  • • Option C. Upper abdominal surgery: Upper abdominal surgeries are associated with a higher risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. The diaphragmatic movement can be impaired after these surgeries, leading to decreased lung expansion and atelectasis, especially in the bases of the lungs. This can increase the chances of postoperative pneumonia and other respiratory issues.
  • • Option C. Upper abdominal surgery:
  • • Option D. Age > 70 years: Advanced age is a recognized risk factor for postoperative complications, including pulmonary complications. Older patients often have reduced physiological reserve, which means they have less ability to compensate for postoperative stress and changes in lung function. Furthermore, they are more likely to have comorbid conditions that can contribute to respiratory issues.
  • • Option D. Age > 70 years:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Well-controlled asthma is not a significant risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications, unlike other conditions such as obesity, upper abdominal surgery, and advanced age.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pgs 2591-2594

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of laryngeal cancer is undergoing a modified radical neck dissection under general anesthesia. During the procedure, the patient is placed in a head-up position for better surgical access. Suddenly, the anesthesiologist notices a rapid drop in end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, accompanied by hypotension and new-onset cardiac arrhythmias. The surgeon reports that the internal jugular vein was being manipulated at the time of the event. What is the most likely cause of these intraoperative symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Venous air embolism is a serious intraoperative complication that occurs when air enters the venous circulation, typically during surgeries involving the head, neck, or chest, particularly when the patient is in a head-up position. Key indicators in this scenario include:
  • • Bleeding or manipulation of the internal jugular vein, which can act as an entry point for air; A sudden and significant drop in ETCO2 due to impaired pulmonary perfusion caused by the air obstructing pulmonary blood flow; Hypotension resulting from decreased venous return and right heart obstruction; and The use of a head-up position during neck surgery, which lowers venous pressure in the neck veins, facilitating air entry.
  • • Bleeding or manipulation of the internal jugular vein, which can act as an entry point for air;
  • • A sudden and significant drop in ETCO2 due to impaired pulmonary perfusion caused by the air obstructing pulmonary blood flow;
  • • Hypotension resulting from decreased venous return and right heart obstruction; and
  • • The use of a head-up position during neck surgery, which lowers venous pressure in the neck veins, facilitating air entry.
  • • These findings strongly suggest venous air embolism, a condition requiring immediate intervention to prevent severe hemodynamic compromise.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Myocardial infarction : While myocardial infarction can cause hypotension and arrhythmias, it would not present with a sudden drop in ETCO2. It typically manifests with chest pain, ECG changes, and elevated cardiac markers, none of which are associated with venous air embolism.
  • • Option A. Myocardial infarction
  • • Option C. Anaphylactic reaction : Anaphylaxis might present with hypotension, tachycardia, and bronchospasm, but it often includes skin manifestations such as rash and flushing, along with airway swelling. It does not typically cause a rapid drop in ETCO2 due to pulmonary air obstruction.
  • • Option C. Anaphylactic reaction
  • • Option D. Tension pneumothorax : Tension pneumothorax could cause hypotension and respiratory distress, but it is more often associated with decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on the affected side. It would not explain the sudden drop in ETCO2 seen in this case, which is more characteristic of venous air embolism.
  • • Option D. Tension pneumothorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Venous air embolism is a potential risk during surgeries involving manipulation of veins, especially in head-up positions. It presents with a sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and arrhythmias due to the air obstructing pulmonary blood flow. Recognizing these signs and promptly managing the embolism is essential to prevent significant hemodynamic compromise.

questions.text: On your evening walk in the park, you notice an unconscious man lying on the ground. What would you do next? ( INICET Nov 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse.

options.label: B
options.text: Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.correct_answer: B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse: This is the recommended sequence in most bystander situations. Firstly, ensure scene safety (make sure you're not putting yourself or the individual in further danger). Then, call for help or ask someone nearby to do so. This ensures that professional medical help is on the way. After calling for help, you’d check the pulse and breathing. If the person is not breathing and/or doesn’t have a pulse, you would start CPR. If an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is available and the person doesn’t have a pulse, you would use it as soon as possible.
  • • Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse: While checking the pulse and starting CPR is correct, calling for help first ensures that professional medical assistance is on the way, which is crucial for the best chance of survival.
  • • Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse:
  • • Option C. Observe: This is not the recommended approach. Immediate intervention is critical when someone is unconscious, especially if they are not breathing or lack a pulse. Delays in initiating CPR or calling for help can drastically reduce the chance of survival and increase the potential for permanent injury.
  • • Option C. Observe:
  • • Option D. Ignore and continue to walk: This is not an ethical or appropriate response when encountering someone in potential distress. Immediate action can make the difference between life and death.
  • • Option D. Ignore and continue to walk:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ In an emergency situation where someone is unconscious, the immediate steps should be to call for help, check for a pulse and breathing, start CPR if needed, and use a defibrillator if available and the person has no pulse.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pgs
  • ➤ 2715-2716

questions.text: In conditions of starvation, which mechanism is most effective for gluconeogenesis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: Acetyl Co-A stimulation of pyruvate carboxylase

questions.correct_answer: A. Acetyl Co-A stimulation of pyruvate carboxylase
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acetyl Co-A is critical for gluconeogenesis, particularly during fasting when carbohydrate reserves are low. It acts as an allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase, an enzyme that converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate. This conversion is essential for maintaining glucose levels during fasting, as it facilitates the production of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. The presence of acetyl Co-A, derived from the breakdown of fatty acids, triggers these mechanisms, enhancing the gluconeogenic pathway.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Fructose-1, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-1: This process is part of glycolysis, not gluconeogenesis, and acts in the opposite direction by promoting the breakdown of glucose. Option C. Citrate stimulation of acetyl carboxylase: While citrate does stimulate acetyl carboxylase, this enzyme is involved in fatty acid synthesis, not gluconeogenesis. Option D. Fructose-2, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-2: This stimulates glycolysis rather than gluconeogenesis and thus would not be effective in promoting glucose production during starvation.
  • • Option B. Fructose-1, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-1: This process is part of glycolysis, not gluconeogenesis, and acts in the opposite direction by promoting the breakdown of glucose.
  • • Option B. Fructose-1, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-1:
  • • Option C. Citrate stimulation of acetyl carboxylase: While citrate does stimulate acetyl carboxylase, this enzyme is involved in fatty acid synthesis, not gluconeogenesis.
  • • Option C. Citrate stimulation of acetyl carboxylase:
  • • Option D. Fructose-2, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-2: This stimulates glycolysis rather than gluconeogenesis and thus would not be effective in promoting glucose production during starvation.
  • • Option D. Fructose-2, 6-biphosphate stimulation of phosphofructokinase-2:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetyl Co-A is crucial for activating pyruvate carboxylase during gluconeogenesis, particularly in fasting states, helping to maintain glucose levels when dietary intake is low.

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. D

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Paradoxical respiration occurs due to the damage of the phrenic nerve, which is marked as D, in the given image.
  • • The structures marked in the image are:
  • • The structures marked in the image are:
  • • A. Right vagus nerve
  • • B. Left vagus nerve
  • • C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve)
  • • D. Right phrenic nerve
  • • The phrenic nerve provides motor innervation to the diaphragm, the primary muscle of inspiration. Damage or paralysis of one phrenic nerve can cause one hemidiaphragm to rise during inspiration instead of descending as it normally does, leading to paradoxical movement. This is especially noticeable when the patient is in a supine position. If the right phrenic nerve is affected, the right hemidiaphragm will exhibit this paradoxical movement.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Right vagus nerve : The vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve) has a broad distribution and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of many organs in the thorax and abdomen. It also provides sensory innervation to the larynx, trachea, esophagus, and a portion of the external ear. It doesn't innervate the diaphragm directly for its motor function.
  • • Option A
  • • Right vagus nerve
  • • Option B. Left vagus nerve : Similarly to the right vagus, the left vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to many thoracic and abdominal organs but does not control diaphragmatic contractions.
  • • Option B.
  • • Left vagus nerve
  • • Option C . Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve) : This is a branch of the vagus nerve that innervates most intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is important for vocal cord function. Damage to this nerve can lead to hoarseness or voice changes but does not directly affect respiratory mechanics in the manner described.
  • • Option C
  • • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (inferior laryngeal nerve)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paradoxical movements in the chest are as follows:
  • ➤ Paradoxical movements in the chest are as follows:
  • ➤ Paradoxical respiration - the aberrant contraction of the abdomen or chest walls, which causes them to move in rather than out during inhalation. It appears in the flail chest.
  • ➤ Paradoxical respiration - the aberrant contraction of the abdomen or chest walls, which causes them to move in rather than out during inhalation. It appears in the flail chest.
  • ➤ Paradoxical movement of the diaphragm - Normally, during inspiration, the diaphragm descends. Yet, due to diaphragmatic paralysis in phrenic nerve palsy cases, the affected side of the diaphragm moves upward (paradoxical breathing). The gold standard test to find this is to stimulate the phrenic nerve electrically or magnetically while simultaneously recording the transdiaphragmatic pressure and/or the compound muscle action potential. Both fluoroscopy and ultrasonography can show this.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021) Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.
  • ➤ Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates.
  • ➤ Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy.
  • ➤ Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  • ➤ Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  • ➤ Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the preoperative evaluation, the anesthesiologist emphasizes the importance of preoxygenation to ensure adequate oxygen reserves during the intubation process. The patient is positioned comfortably and provided with 100% oxygen. Which of the following is the recommended duration or technique for effective preoxygenation before tracheal intubation?

options.label: A
options.text: 2 minutes of spontaneous breathing with a face mask

options.label: B
options.text: 3 minutes of tidal volume breathing through a face mask

options.label: D
options.text: 5 minutes of normal breathing through nasal cannula

questions.correct_answer: B. 3 minutes of tidal volume breathing through a face mask
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The recommended method for effective preoxygenation involves having the patient breathe 100% oxygen through a tight-fitting face mask for 3 minutes using tidal volume breathing. This technique replaces the nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen, increasing the body’s oxygen reserve and extending the safe apnea period during tracheal intubation. The primary goal of preoxygenation is to maximize oxygen saturation and prolong the time before hypoxemia occurs, providing the anesthesiologist with a critical window to secure the airway safely.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 2 minutes of spontaneous breathing with a face mask: This duration is insufficient for optimal preoxygenation, as it may not completely replace the nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen, resulting in inadequate oxygen reserves during apnea.
  • • Option A.
  • • 2 minutes of spontaneous breathing with a face mask:
  • • Option C. 4 deep breaths over 30 seconds: Although taking four deep breaths over 30 seconds can help increase oxygen levels, it is not as effective as the standard 3 minutes of tidal volume breathing. This technique is sometimes used when time is limited but does not provide the same level of safety.
  • • Option C. 4 deep breaths over 30 seconds:
  • • Option D . 5 minutes of normal breathing through nasal cannula: Preoxygenation with a nasal cannula is less effective than a face mask due to the lower inspired oxygen concentration and potential for room air entrainment, leading to suboptimal preoxygenation.
  • • Option D
  • • 5 minutes of normal breathing through nasal cannula:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Effective preoxygenation before tracheal intubation is best achieved by having the patient breathe 100% oxygen through a tight-fitting face mask for 3 minutes using tidal volume breathing. This process replaces lung nitrogen with oxygen, extending the safe apnea time and enhancing patient safety during airway management

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.

questions.text: As a public health expert, you are consulted about a series of outbreaks in a region that lacks significant prior vaccination campaigns. Given the imperative to contain the spread of disease and protect vulnerable populations, you are asked to prioritize a disease for which mass vaccination would provide the most immediate and impactful reduction in transmission. Which of the following diseases would most benefit from such an intervention? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Polio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polio, due to its potential for rapid spread and severe outcomes, along with the availability of an effective and easily administered vaccine, makes it the most critical focus for a mass vaccination campaign in response to an outbreak. This strategy not only protects individuals but also aids in the global effort to eradicate polio.
  • ➤ Polio, due to its potential for rapid spread and severe outcomes, along with the availability of an effective and easily administered vaccine, makes it the most critical focus for a mass vaccination campaign in response to an outbreak.
  • ➤ This strategy not only protects individuals but also aids in the global effort to eradicate polio.

  • ➤ Outbreak response for Measles includes

questions.text: A baby was born at 34 weeks of pregnancy; the appearance of the baby is given below. What is the mother suffering from? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gestational diabetes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a large for gestational age (LGA) fetus. Macrosomia is a condition where a newborn baby is significantly larger than average. This can often be identified by a higher birth weight and size compared to typical babies born at the same gestational age.
  • • Causes of Macrosomia:
  • • Causes of Macrosomia:
  • • Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) and Overt Diabetes Mellitus: Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia, which stimulates insulin production in the fetus. Insulin acts as a growth hormone, leading to increased fetal growth and fat deposition. Maternal Obesity: Increased maternal body mass index (BMI) is associated with a higher risk of delivering a macrosomic baby. Previous Baby with Macrosomia: A history of delivering a large baby increases the risk of subsequent babies also being large. Post-term Pregnancy: Pregnancy extending beyond the due date increases the chance of the baby growing larger. Excessive Weight Gain in Pregnancy: Significant maternal weight gain during pregnancy contributes to larger fetal size.
